Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 82
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
The patient presented to our clinic for consultation and left ptosis surgery and was previously treated elsewhere for NTG.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient reported normal IOP (14 mmHg) and BCVA of 1.0 and 1.0, right and left eye, respectively. On ophthalmoscopy, both eyes showed glaucomatous changes, but the left eye was more advanced than the right. In addition, only the left eye exhibited VF changes typical for glaucoma that corresponded ideally with a retinal nerve fiber layer thickness defect in OCT examinations.

Further examination revealed a 4 x 4mm pituitary microadenoma that was found to be contacting the chiasm. While the cause of this condition is unclear, the patientâ€™s condition remained stable throughout his observation with no change in visual field or tumor size.

Diagnosis:
The patient presented with unilateral stable glaucoma with coexisting pituitary adenoma.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was given a detailed follow-up plan upon discharge and scheduled for routine follow-up appointments with his ophthalmologist and endocrinologist.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to monitor any changes in vision and immediately report any symptoms to his ophthalmologist. He was also asked to continue monitoring his pituitary microadenoma under the supervision of his endocrinologist.

Referrals/Consultations:
The patient was referred to an endocrinologist for the management of his pituitary microadenoma.

Procedures/Treatments:
The patient underwent left ptosis surgery.

Condition Upon Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with no complications.

Signed: [Redacted].
